title: College Planning Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of 529 plans, student loans, financial aid, and alternative funding strategies for college.

questions.question: What is the primary tax advantage of a 529 college savings plan?
options: Earnings grow tax-free and withdrawals for qualified expenses are tax-free
You can withdraw money anytime for any purpose tax-free
questions.explanation: 529 plans offer tax-free growth and tax-free withdrawals when used for qualified education expenses. While some states offer tax deductions for contributions, there is no federal deduction. The tax-free compounding over 18+ years is the primary benefit.

questions.question: What happens to unused 529 plan funds if the beneficiary doesn't attend college?
options: The funds are forfeited to the state
You can change the beneficiary to another family member without penalty
You must pay a 50% penalty on all withdrawals
questions.explanation: 529 plans offer flexibility—you can change the beneficiary to another qualifying family member without penalty. You can also withdraw funds for non-education purposes (paying income tax and a 10% penalty on earnings), or starting in 2024, roll up to $35,000 to a Roth IRA for the beneficiary under certain conditions.

questions.question: What is the key difference between subsidized and unsubsidized federal student loans?
options: Subsidized loans have lower interest rates
The government pays interest on subsidized loans while you're in school
Subsidized loans never need to be repaid
Unsubsidized loans are only available to graduate students
questions.explanation: For subsidized federal loans, the government pays the interest while you're enrolled at least half-time, during grace periods, and during deferment. For unsubsidized loans, interest accrues from disbursement, and you're responsible for all interest charges.

questions.question: What is a good rule of thumb for total student loan borrowing?
options: Borrow as much as you need regardless of future salary
Don't borrow more than your expected first-year salary
Borrow twice your expected annual salary
questions.explanation: A common guideline is to keep total student debt below your expected first-year salary. This typically results in manageable monthly payments of 10-15% of income. Borrowing significantly more can lead to financial stress and difficulty making payments.

questions.question: When does the FAFSA open for the following academic year?
questions.explanation: The FAFSA opens October 1 each year for the following academic year. It's important to file as early as possible because some aid is awarded on a first-come, first-served basis. The FAFSA uses tax information from two years prior, allowing early filing.

questions.question: How are student assets assessed differently than parent assets for financial aid?
options: Student assets are assessed at 5.64%, parent assets at 20%
Student assets are assessed at 20%, parent assets at 5.64%
questions.explanation: Student assets are assessed at 20% for financial aid calculations, while parent assets are assessed at only 5.64%. This means money in a student's name has a much larger impact on aid eligibility, which is why it's often better to keep savings in parent-owned accounts or 529 plans.

questions.question: How much can starting at community college save compared to four years at a university?
questions.explanation: Starting at community college for two years and transferring to a four-year university can save $40,000-$80,000 or more compared to attending a university for all four years. Community college tuition is typically $3,000-$5,000 per year versus $10,000-$50,000+ at universities.

questions.question: What is the maximum tax-free educational assistance employers can provide annually under Section 127?
questions.explanation: Under Section 127 of the tax code, employers can provide up to $5,250 per year in tax-free educational assistance. Many employers offer this benefit, and some provide more (though amounts over $5,250 are taxable as income).

questions.question: What does the Post-9/11 GI Bill cover for veterans?
options: Full in-state tuition, housing allowance, and books stipend
questions.explanation: The Post-9/11 GI Bill provides comprehensive benefits including full in-state tuition at public universities, a monthly housing allowance, and a books and supplies stipend for up to 36 months of education—worth over $100,000 in many cases.

questions.question: Which strategy can help you graduate college faster and save money?
options: Earning AP or CLEP credits before or during college
questions.explanation: Earning college credits through AP exams ($95 each), CLEP exams ($89 each), or dual enrollment can significantly reduce time to degree. Passing 8 AP exams could save an entire year of college, saving $10,000-$30,000+ in tuition, fees, and living expenses.
